The group leader of this small group is Moreen N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items. Moreen is 27 years old and is married with a husband, who sells spare parts for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 2 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Moreen makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more business stock. Moreen has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to pay rent for the shop premises and the loan was paid back on time.

Moreen is joined in her small group by Magret N., Josephine N., Mary N., and Jesca N.. Magret N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase more furniture like tables. Josephine N. is currently operating a business in tailoring and wants a loan to buy more cloth material and fabrics. Mary N. operates a business of fresh food sales and wants to purchase more foods to sell. Jesca N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add capital stock.

loan.use: To add more commodities to retail shop

loan.name: Zohra's Group

texts.en:
I am Zohra M. from the mid-sized city Faisalabad. I was married 22 years ago and I have three boys and three girls. All of my children attend school, except one who is currently working. My husband is a retired army officer. I stitch clothes for my neighborhood clients and I now want to expand my stitching business. My loan group members are: Rahat B., whose husband trades livestock; Nasreen B., who will use her share of loan to pay off the remaining installments on their cow; Rehana M., who will buy a rickshaw for her husband; and Shakoran S., who requires this loan for her brother who sells fruit. This loan group has been together for one year and has shown a great sense of responsibility.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Expand stitching business

loan.name: Kabumbi V D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Florence is 21 years old and is single. Each week, Namuyimba makes approximately UGX 55000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in a sweater knitting business. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy a sewing machine and the loan was paid back on time.

Namuyimba is joined in her small group by Ritah K., Ruth N., Farida N., and Susan N.. Ritah K. has a salon and cosmetic shop business and wants to purchase a hair dryer. Ruth N. is currently operating a business selling paraffin and wants a loan to add more working capital. Farida N. operates a cosmetic sales business and wants to increase stock. Susan N. is currently in the business of fresh food sales and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loan.use: To boost tailoring business

loan.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nazia S.. I am married and a mother of two: one boy and one girl. I live with my family in the mid-sized industrial city of Faisalabad, Pakistan. I stitch clothes for women of my neighborhood and my husband runs a grocery store. My husband needs a loan to improve his business. The higher profits that we hope to receive will be saved for our children's future. I would like to borrow in a group: Shalika Shrafat needs this loan to buy pesticides and fertilizers for their fields, Parween A. plans to start a grocery store and Shahnaz A. will invest her share of the loan in her husbands auto lubricants store. All of these women are hardworking entrepreneurs and dream of a prosperous life for their families.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Improve a grocery store

loan.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
My name is Razia M.. I am borrowing for the first time for my husbands milk shop, which he has run for the past six years. He sells milk, yogurt and butter at his shop. I am the group leader of four other women. all of whom need loans for their businesses. Shamshad R. needs this loan to start a grocery store, Rubina B. intends to expand their vegetable business. Parween B. will use the loan to buy stock for their grocery store. Shamshad S. plans to start a fruit-selling corner business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Expand milk sales shop

loan.name: Kabumbi Iii A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty K.. She is currently in the business of fresh food sales and is requesting a loan to add more stock. Betty is 41 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 8 children ranging from age 4 to 25 and six of her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy sacks of food from villages and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Betty N., Mary S., Rebecca K., and Molly N.. Betty N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Mary S. is currently operating a business selling breakables and wants a loan to make shelves. Rebecca K. operates a business selling firewood and wants to increase her inventory. Molly N. is currently in the business of selling cosmetics and is requesting a loan to purchase more lotions, oils and perfumes.

loan.use: To stock more fresh foods to sell

loan.name: Kabumbi Iii B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Damalie K.. She is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Damalie is 29 years old and is single. She has 1 child aged 3. Each week, Damalie makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house. Damalie has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to rent a piece of land for brick laying and the loan was paid back on time.

Damalie is joined in her small group by Beatrice K., Rosemary R., Joan S., and Justine N.. Beatrice K. has a business selling clothes and wants to boost business. Rosemary R. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Joan S. operates a business of used clothing sales and wants to increase inventory. Justine N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to add more working capital.

loan.use: To add capital to brick business

loan.name: Kabumbi Iii C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Nuru N.. She is currently in the business of selling spare parts and firewood and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of spare parts. Nuru is 47 years old and is married with a husband who is a doctor for work. She has 9 children ranging from age 3 to 27 and her children go to school. Each week, Nuru makes approximately UGX 150000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for the children's needs. Nuru has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to purchase spare parts and the loan was paid back on time.

Nuru is joined in her small group by Farida N. , Jamida N., Teopista N., and Lamula N.. Farida N. has a business in livestock farming and wants to purchase livestock feed. Jamida N. is currently operating a farming business and wants a loan to buy good quality seed. Teopista N. operates a business selling local brew and wants to purchase more jerry cans of brew. Lamula N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loan.use: To purchase more spare parts to sell and also to add to her firewood business

loan.name: Ndi

texts.en:
Ndi E. was born in 1982, is single and a mother of two children. Due to poverty, she dropped out of school. Motivated by these circumstance she became a member of GHAPE in 2005, after being trained in business and management skills and with a loan of $40 she started her off-license where she can now boost of a daily income to take care of her self and children.

She plans to add more drinks in her store, educate her children and take care of their needs with the profit of this loan.

She plans to repay the loan in 18months. Repayment will start in the fourth month after disbursement.

loan.use: Purchase of drinks

loan.name: Kabumbi Iii D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Aida N.. She is currently in the business of selling timber and is requesting a loan to purchase more timber to sell. Aida is 30 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 1 to 6 and only one goes to school. Each week, Aida makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a timber cutting machine. Aida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy more timber and the loan was paid back on time.

Aida is joined in her small group by Sarah N., Faida N., Loy N., and Sarah N.. Sarah N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to invest in the business. Faida N. is currently operating a business selling timber and wants a loan to buy a timber cutting machine. Loy N. operates a retail shop business and wants to add stock to the shop. Sarah N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.

loan.use: To expand timber business

loan.name: Ocheng A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mayi N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop commodities. Mayi is 28 years old and is single. Each week, Mayi makes approximately UGX 11000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Mayi has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 700000 in order to add stock to the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Mayi is joined in her small group by Jackline K., Hamida N., Jane N., and Miriam N.. Jackline K. has a business providing a public pay phone and wants to purchase more airtime cards. Hamida N. is currently operating a business selling fresh food and wants a loan to add to the business. Jane N. operates a business of chicken rearing and wants to buy chicken feed. Miriam N. is currently in the business of operating a piggery and is requesting a loan to purchase more piglets.

loan.use: To boost retail shop business and make more profits

loan.name: Tong

texts.en:
Mrs. Tong P., 37, is a chicken seller in the market. She makes on average about $4 a day in profit.

To earn more, her husband, Mr. Tom Hoeun, 46, works as a construction laborer and earns $4 a day.

They have eight children. Two of them work in a garment factory and earn a salary of $60 a month.

This family needs to generate more income by purchasing pigs to breed. Because half of the family members don't earn any money, Mrs. Tong P. hopes that raising pigs will bring in revenue.

loan.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase pigs to breed.

loan.name: Ocheng B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Madina N.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty parlor and is requesting a loan to buy more cosmetics.

Madina is joined in her small group by Rose Namirimu, Viola N., Luyiga F., and Harriet N.. Rose Namirimu has a business running a beauty salon and wants to purchase more hair oils and chemicals. Viola N. is currently operating a business selling fresh foods and wants a loan to add capital. Luyiga F. operates a business of poultry farming and wants to buy chicken feed. Harriet N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase new cloth material.

loan.use: To add more working capital and expand business

loan.name: Pin

texts.en:
Mrs. Pin A. is a widow with four children who stays at home looking after the house and cooking food for her family members.

After her housework, she takes time to braid cotton scarves, which normally earns her around $1 a day in profit.

Two of her daughters work in the factory and earn $4 a day. Another one sells sugarcane juice in front of the factory and typically makes $5 of income.

Now Mrs. Pin A. is looking for a loan from Kiva for about $900 to purchase a motorbike and a machine (this machine people use to squeeze sugarcane in order to extract the juice) to help cover the living expenses.

loan.use: She will use this loan to purchase a motorbike and a machine to squeeze sugarcane.

loan.name: Ocheng C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose N.. She is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Rose is 26 years old and is single. She has 1 child aged 2 who doesnt go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 16000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her child. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to purchase more clothes and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Gorette N., Farida N., Josephine S., and Rose K.. N. has a business making and selling snacks and wants to buy baking flour and other ingredients. Farida N. is currently operating a business selling fresh food and wants a loan to purchase more food. Josephine S. operates a business selling clothes and wants to add working capital. Rose K. is currently in the business of selling fresh foods and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loan.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loan.name: Tim

texts.en:
Mrs. Tim S., 42, is a mother of three children and works as a pig raiser and farmer. Normally, she earns approximately $1.50 a day.

To supplement the household, her husband works purchasing recyclable items in his community and resells them to the plant for profit.

One of her children lives away from home, while the other two are students.

To improve the business, they have plans to purchase a motorbike to transfer the recyclable items to the factory whenever he collects them from his neighbors.

To purchase a motorbike, they are requesting a loan from Kiva of around $300.

loan.use: This couple expects to use this loan to purchase a motorbike to transfer recyclable items.

loan.name: Thim

texts.en:
Mrs. Thim S., 51, is a vendor of natural medicines, selling door to door in her village. She normally earns $3 a day.

To increase the family's livelihood, her husband works as a farmer and earns a profit of less than $1 a day.

They have three children. One works collecting recyclable items and resells them to the plant and earns on average around $2 a day. This couple aims to purchase a motorbike to take the recyclable items to the plant. Now the products are transported by bicycle.

This couple hopes to get a loan from Kiva of $600 to purchase a motorbike.

loan.use: This couple aims to purchase a motorbike to take recyclable items to the plant

loan.name: Ocheng D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Getrude N.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for sale. Getrude is 41 years old and is a widow. She has 4 children ranging from age 7 to 15 and only one goes to school. Each week, Getrude makes approximately UGX 75000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide maximum health services to the family. Getrude has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1000000 in order to add more clothes to the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Getrude is joined in her small group by Berna N., Rose N., Sarah M., and Mastula N.. Berna N. has a beauty salon business and wants to purchase more braids, hair oils and chemicals. Rose N. is currently operating a piggery business and wants a loan to buy more piglets. Sarah M. operates a business selling fresh food and wants to boost business. Mastula N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth material.

loan.use: To increase clothes business inventory

loan.name: Mariana

texts.en: Mariana C. lives with her family in Rudozem, near Smolian, Bulgaria. Rudozem is a tourist town in one of the greatest mountain regions of Bulgaria, the Rhodope Mountains. Mariana and her husband are teachers and she teaches English at the town's school. Because of the tourist development in the region, Mariana decided to start bed and breakfast business and rent two of the rooms in their big house. Therefore, Mariana has applied for a loan of $775 (1,000 BGN) to make repairs on two rooms she wants to rent.

loan.use: To improve bed and breakfast accommodations.

loan.name: An

texts.en:
Mrs. An L., 23, is a mother of one child. She works together with her husband as a potato seller and makes on average $20 of income.

This couple hopes to grow their business by purchasing more potatoes and reselling them along the Vietnamese border. It is the right time to grow the business to create good living conditions for the family.

They are now requesting a loan from Kiva of $700 to buy potatoes.

loan.use: Use this loan to purchase more potatoes and resell the at the Vietnam border

loan.name: Krasimir

texts.en: Krasimir V. is a carpenter and is specialized in producing wooden kitchen equipment. He is single and lives in the town of Smolian. Krasimir has run his business for more than five years and would like to increase production. He has applied for a loan of $1,000 (1,300 BGN) to purchase more wood supplies.

loan.use: To buy more wood supplies.

loan.name: Rumen

texts.en: Rumen V. and his wife retired five years ago, and shortly thereafter began farming. They own 60 acres of land in the village of Pavelsko, near Smolian, Bulgaria, on which they grow potatoes. Rumen is applying for a loan of $775 (1,000 BGN) to buy potatoes seeds and seedlings for his farm.

loan.use: To buy potatoes seeds and seedlings.

loan.name: Chut

texts.en:
Mrs. Chut H., 45, is a widow with one child and works making cakes to sell in the market.

Typically, she earns $2.90 a day in profit. Her daughter works in the factory and normally makes on average $1.60 a day in profit.

Mrs. Chut H. wants to improve her business and is now requesting a loan from Kiva of about $400 to purchase rice, sugar and beans to make a large number of cakes to sell. The rest of the money she will use to buy pigs to raise for additional revenue.

loan.use: She will use this loan to purchase rice, sugar and beans to make cakes to sell in the market.

loan.name: Angel

texts.en: Angel Bebelekov is 57 years old and lives in the town of Smolian, Bulgaria. He was a sculptor but three years ago decided to start an apiary, and since then has steadily improved his bee-keeping business . Angel currently has five bee hives and wants to expand his business by buying three more. He has applied for a loan of $775 (1,000 BGN).

loan.use: To buy three more bee hives.

loan.name: Ocheng E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mastula N.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase poultry feed. Mastula is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a taxi driver for work. She has 3 children who go to school. Each week, Mastula makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her children. Mastula has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more chicken feed and chicks and the loan was paid back on time.

Mastula is joined in her small group by Janet N., Ruth N., Mariam N., and Eva N.. Janet N. has a business in hardware sales and wants to increase stock in the hardware shop. Ruth N. is currently operating a business selling fresh foods and wants a loan to add to the business. Mariam N. operates a business selling fresh food and wants to expand business. Eva N. is currently in the business of selling hair braids and is requesting a loan to add more capital.

loan.use: To add to poultry farming business and expand it

loan.name: Evgeni

texts.en: Evgeni M. is 38 years old. He is married and has two sons. Evgeni is a saw mill operator and for many years has had a small workshop for wooden materials. He works alone, although sometimes one of his sons helps him. Evgeni wants to buy a new motor saw to improve his work, and has applied for a loan of $775 (1,000 BGN).

loan.use: To buy a new motor saw.

loan.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Mrs. Chuon S., 27, owns a plot of farmland where she grows rice and makes on average $1 a day.

Her husband, Mr. Em Mon, 31, operates a trailer and earns $6.66 a day of income. As now his trailer is broken, he needs some money from Kiva to fix it (to repair the trailer costs about $200). The rest of the $600 loan will be used to purchase a water pump to water the rice field, as in dry season is difficult without water.

loan.use: Hopes to use this loan to fix a trailer and purchase a water pump.

loan.name: Tiv

texts.en:
Mrs. Tiv S., 39, is a mother of two children and works as a duck and chicken seller in the market. She normally earns on average about $3 in profit.

Her husband is a motor mechanic who earns around $5 a day.

One of their children is a motor mechanic like his father and the other is a student.

To improve their business and earn more profit to sustain their livelihood, they are now requesting a loan from Kiva in the amount of $800 to purchase more chickens, ducks, rice and motor tools.

loan.use: Requesting a loan from Kiva in the amount of $800 to purchase more chickens, ducks, rice and motor tools.

loan.name: Aleksi

texts.en: Aleksi D. worked as a technician at a water supply company for more than 35 years. After retiring, he started own business by opening a garage for electric car repairs. He lives in the town of Smolian, Bulgaria, and is known as one of the best auto electric mechanics in the town. Now he needs $1,000 (1,300 BGN) to buy a special electricity measuring tool.

loan.use: To buy a special electricity meter.

loan.name: Nabweru North Ii Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Margret S.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to buy more poultry feed. Margret is 44 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children ranging from age 7 to 28 and three of her children go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 55000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to the business. Margret has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy poultry feed and the loan was paid back on time.

Margret is joined in her small group by Safina N., Grace K. and Nansamba K.. Safina N. has a business selling fresh foods and wants to increase stock. Grace K. is currently operating a business trading goats and wants a loan to purchase more goats from villages. Nansamba K. operates a drug shop business and wants to purchase more drugs to sell.

loan.use: To add working capital to poultry business

loan.name: Nadejda

texts.en: Nadejda B. is 56 years old and has worked for more than 20 years in a sartorial company in the town of Smolian, Bulgaria. The company she works for often gives its employees tailoring to do at home for extra payment. The company supplies all the necessary materials. Nadejda needs $775 (1,000 BGN) to buy a new sewing machine in order to improve her work as a tailor.

loan.use: To buy a new sewing machine.

loan.name: Sevdalin

texts.en: Sevdalin C. lives in the town of Smolian, Bulgaria. He is married with one child. His wife has her own flower-selling business. Sevdalin used to work as a brigade leader in a big factory but four years ago he founded his own workshop and started a carpentry business. He produces wooden frameworks and is recognized as one of the best producers in the region. Sevdalin needs $1,000 (1,300 BNG) to buy a new grind machine for his business.

loan.use: To buy a new grind machine.

loan.name: Guljahon

texts.ru:
Guljahon N. lives in Yavan. She is 31 years old, is married and has 2 children. Guljahon has a college education and works as a high school teacher. In addition she raises livestock and owns dairy cows. She uses the milk for her family and for sale to wholesalers. This business allows Guljahon to earn an additional income and to provide markets with fresh milk. She plans to use her loan to buy an addition cow. She will thereby increase milk production and her income. She plans to pay back the loan over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

. 31 , 2 . , . . . . . . . , . 10 .

loan.use: Purchase a dairy cow

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Mahmadsharif

texts.ru:
Mahmadsharif J. lives in Yavan. He is 42 years old, is married and has 4 children. Mahmadsharif has a secondary/technical education and is a driver by profession. He sells food products and has a sales point in the center of the region. Mahmadsharif brings products from Dushanbe which allows locals to make purchases in their region instead of traveling for shopping. Mahmadsharif will use his loan to increase his inventory and will pay back the loan over 7 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

. 42 , 4 . - . . . . . . . 7 .

loan.use: Purchase products for sale

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Beltha

texts.en:
Beltha E. was born in 1959; she is a widow and a mother of 5 children. Things became very difficult for her when her husband died. She depended on her husband because her parents died when she was still very young. She was forced into marriage immediately after the death of her father. She is not educated and she depended greatly on her husbands daily income until his death. With all of these difficulties and too much sickness on her part, she was convinced to join GHAPE in 1999 by a very good friend.

She took out loans of $30 in 1999, $100 in 2000, $100 in 2001, and $200 in 2002. She invested the loans in farming of yams and cassava. Her achievements are countless, she pays schools fees to her children, spent some to learn a trade, and lastly she repaired her house.

Given a loan, she plans to continue her farm work, and believes that her business will be successful because she has experience in farming of yam and cassava. With the profits, she intends to educate her children, save some money, and provide food for her family.

loan.use: Farming of yams and cassava

loan.name: Bweyogerere A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Racheal M.. She is currently in the business of running a bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more beers to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Racheal hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Racheal is joined in her small group by Getrude N., Madina N., Jennifer K., and Scovia A.. Getrude N. has a beauty salon business and wants to by more hair oils and chemicals. Madina N. is currently operating a business in charcoal selling and wants a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal for sale. Jennifer K. operates a retail shop business and wants to add to the business. Scovia A. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loan.use: To boost bar business

loan.name: Christina

texts.en:
Born in 1965, Christina M. is a widow with 2 children. Faced with the heavy load of educating her children single handedly, she joined GHAPE in 2007.

Given a loan, she plans to farm cassava and yams, and raise fowl. With the training she obtained from GHAPE in management skills, and given the fact that she is strong and healthy, she believes she will be able to repay this loan in the required time. With the profit, she intends to educate her children, save some money, and provide food for her family.

She plans to repay the loan in 12 months.

loan.use: Growing of cassava/yams and raising chickens

payment.comment: correction due to overpayment for business 37937

loan.name: Zulfiay

texts.ru:
Zulfiay M. live in Yavan, she is 27 years old, is married and has 4 children. She has a secondary specialized education and is a tailor by profession. She sews dresses to order and for sale. Zulfiay has been in this business for 10 years. She will use her loan to purchase fabric to make national dresses. This business is the main source of income for her family and also gives locals access to these services at affordable prices. She plans to pay back the loan over a 10 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

. 27 , 4 . -. . . 10 . . . . 10 .

loan.use: Purchase fabric

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Min

texts.en:
Mrs. Min S. is a widow with four children and works as a vendor of grocery products. She usually earns $4 a day in profit.

Two of her children are garment workers, one is farmer and last one works in security. All of them normally earn around $1 to $1.50 a day.

Mrs. Min S.s business is growing, so she wants to purchase more products to sell. She hopes to use a loan of $700 from Kiva to expand her business by purchasing more grocery products. She wants to provide her family with good living conditions.

loan.use: Hopes to use this loan to purchase more grocery products.

loan.name: Bweyogerere B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence B.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to expand business. Florence is 29 years old and is single. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 60000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her sisters' and brothers' education. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Josephine N., Perusi N., Sarah N., and Eva N.. Josephine N. has a business selling matooke and wants to add working capital. Perusi N. is currently operating a business selling vegetables and wants a loan to increase stock. Sarah N. operates a business of charcoal selling and wants to add to the business. Eva N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for sale.

loan.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loan.name: Bweyogerere C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Dorothy N.. She is currently in the business of running a bar and is requesting a loan to buy more crates of beers. Dorothy is 36 years old and is married. Her husband has a butchery business. She has 7 children ranging from age 5 to 22 and four of them go to school. Each week, Dorothy makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Dorothy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 in order to invest in the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Dorothy is joined in her small group by Hadijah N., Proscovia N., Lazira N., and Christine N.. Hadijah N. has a business selling matooke and wants to increase capital stock. Proscovia N. is currently operating a canteen business and wants a loan to stock more commodities. Lazira N. operates a business selling clothes and wants to expand business. Christine N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add more working capital.

loan.use: To add to bar business

loan.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en:
I am Kaneez T. from the small city of Kot Radha Kishan, which is famous in Pakistan for its milk production. I was born in the second largest city, Lahore, Pakistan, but then moved to KRK after my marriage 15 years ago. I have six boys and one girl. All of my children attend school and I wish them a bright future. In the morning my husband sells cloth in his shop and he drives a rickshaw in the evening. These two businesses generate decent profits for us, but my husband feels that as our children are growing so are their needs, and therefore we want to save for their higher education. As a result, we have decided to expand our cloth business and hence we need a loan. I would like this loan in a group with five other women. These women are needy and want financial assistance to grow their businesses. Haleema B. wants a loan for their restaurant. Parween B. will buy a donkey cart. Sumaira A. plans to invest her share of the loan in her familys tailoring shop. Basheeran B. is borrowing for her husbands clothing sales business. Rasheeda B. will invest in her son's mobile phone shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Expand a cloth selling business

loan.name: Shorahim

texts.ru:
Shorahim A. lives in Yavan. He is 50 years old, is married and has 3 children. He has a high school education. Shorahim sells vegetables at the city market. He purchases the vegetables from wholesalers and then sells them individually at a higher price. He has been in this business for 17 years and is the sole income earner in his family. Shorahim will use his loan to expand his inventory. He will pay back the loan over a 10 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

, . 50 . 3 . . . . 17 , . . 10 .

loan.use: Purchase vegetables for sale

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
My name is Samina K.. I reside in Kot Radha Kishan with my husband and eight children: two boys and six girls. Both boys and four of the girls attend school, whereas the younger two are small. My husband sells fruit on his fruit cart in a nearby busy market. There are three other women in my loan group: Sakina B. sells cloth, Nasreen B. sells various electronics on installments, Sughran B. runs a cosmetics store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Expand a fruit-selling business

loan.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
My name is Safia E. U.. I have been living at Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, for the last 25 years. I am a mother of six girls, all of whom are less than 13 years old. Five of the girls attend school, but the youngest is not of school age yet. I send my children to school because I do not want them to remain uneducated like me. My husband is the only breadwinner of the family and he works in a local factory. Because my husbands income is small, I sell clothing to supplement his earnings. My group members are: Bushra B., who is borrowing for her familys mobile phone store; Shugufta B., who will invest her share of loan in their breakfast stall; Nagina B., whose husband operates a milk sales shop; and Parween B., who needs to buy dates for her husbands fruit cart. I completely trust these women and want to help them escape poverty.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: Expand a clothing sales business

loan.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Mr. Kodjo V. was born in Lom on March 9, 1964 and is married and the father of 7 children. He founded and directs a primary school located in his neighborhood of Hdzranawo and is asking for a loan for the school from Kiva. The money from the loan will be used to outfit two classrooms so that the pupils can study in a good environment. Making this project a reality will considerably improve chances for the success of his little school and his pupils this school year.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur V. Kodjo est n Lom le 09 Mars 1964, mari et pre de sept (7) enfants. Gestionnaire, il est le fondateur dune cole primaire sise dans son quartier Hdzranawo et sollicite travers ce projet un financement sous forme de prt. Ce fonds lui servira lamnagement de 2 salles de classe pour une bonne condition de travail et dtude des lves. La ralisation de ce projet augmentera sensiblement un bon rendement en fin danne par consquent le potentiel ducatif trouvera son essor.

loan.use:
Outfitting of classrooms

Amenagement de salles de classes

loan.name: Kigandazi A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Lubowa A.. She is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling. Lubowa is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 3 children ranging from age 5 to 11 and her children go to school. Each week, Lubowa makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a deep freezer. Lubowa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Lubowa is joined in her small group by Rebecca K., Grace K., A. N., and Teo N.. Rebecca K. has a business in poultry keeping and wants to purchase more chicken feed. Grace K. is currently operating a beauty salon business and wants a loan to buy a hair dryer, oils and mirrors. A. N. operates a business of selling matooke and wants to purchase more bunches of matooke. Teo N. is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loan.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell

loan.name: Therese

texts.fr:
Born in Brazzavile in the Republic of the Congo on April 6, 1964, Mrs. Thrse H. is divorced and has one child to raise. Her business is selling carbonated and brewed beverages and she runs a bar. Since she is faced with frequently running short of drinks, she risks losing her clientele. She is asking for a small loan so that she can purchase a bigger stock of drinks and also add sales of canned goods, pasta and such to meet her customer demand. This will allow her to augment her income so that she can become financially independent.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Ne Brazzaville dans la Rpublique Congolaise le 06 Avril 1964, Madame H. Thrse est divorce avec un (1) enfant charge. Son activit est bas sur la vente de boissons gazeuses et sucreries brasses (BB) et est dtentrice dun Bar. Souvent confront de frquente rupture de stock, ce qui lui fait perdre sa clientle. Elle sollicite un appui financier pour pouvoir sapprovisionner en grande quantit de boissons, et associer la vente des produits alimentaires (botes de conserve, pattes alimentaires et divers) sur la demande de sa clientle. Ceci lui permettra daugmenter davantage ses revenus en vue davoir un autonomie financire.

loan.use:
Stocking drinks and food products for re-sale

Approvisionnement en boissons et en produits alimentaires

loan.name: Threse Afoua

texts.fr:
Born in Lom on July 14, 1975, Mrs. Thrse Afoua B. is divorced and is responsible for six persons. She trained as a seamstress but she does not have an appropriate workshop where she can do her sewing, so she is asking for a small loan. This will allow her to purchase a new sewing machine and rent a workshop. The very positive evolution of her business venture makes it necessary for Mrs. B. to have more capital at her disposition. This plan will bring in supplementary income so that she will be better able to support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Ne Lom le 14 Juillet 1975, Madame B. Afoua Thrse est divorce et en charge six (6) personnes. Couturire de formation, elle ne dispose pas dun atelier de couture appropri pour exercer son mtier et sollicite donc un financement sous forme de crdit. Ce fonds lui permettra dune part acqurir une nouvelle machine coudre et louer un atelier. Lvolution trs positive de ses activits oblige Madame B. disposer plus de moyens financiers et ce projet lui apportera un revenu supplmentaire pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loan.use:
Purchase of a sewing machine and rental of a workshop

Achat de machine a coudre et location d'atelier

loan.name: Yatim

texts.ru:
Yatim K. lives in Yavan, he is 52 years old, is married and has 4 children. He has a secondary/technical education. He earns his living by purchasing and reselling fruits and vegetables. Today, this is the sole source of income for his family. Yatim will use his loan to increase his product assortment. He will pay back the loan over a 10 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

. 52 . , 4 . - . , . : .). . . 10 .

loan.use: Increase product assortment

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Ramiza

texts.en: Ramiza was born in 1974 and she lives in Motre, a suburb of Visoko. Ramiza does agricultural seasonal work with her husband. Their monthly incomes are 300 KM. They have about 150 KM of additional monthly income from the government. Ramiza wants to invest this loan of 1200 KM in agriculture. She intends to expand the business and improve her living standards.

loan.use: Invest in agriculture.

loan.name: Vannak

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna V.,28, lives in Teok Nem village in Kandal province. She is a farmer and grows crops to support her family. She is a widow with three children who have yet to attend school. She is asking for a loan which will allow her to buy fertilizer, plow her rice field and dig a well to support her rice field.

loan.use: To dig a well, buy fertilizer, and plow her rice field.

loan.name: Amira

texts.en: Amira is from Porjeani, a small village near Visoko. She is a 39-year-old housewife and she has 2 children, 15 and 18 years old. Amira does agriculture with her husband, who has a full-time job. His monthly income is 800 KM. Amira want to use this loan of 1000 KM to buy seedlings and seeds. They want to improve their business in order to secure a safe future for their children.

loan.use: Buying seedlings and seeds.

loan.name: Dd Kafui

texts.fr:
Born in Lom on January 26, 1949, Mrs. Dd Kafui E. is married and responsible for 5 persons. She is retired but has taken up selling clothing and cosmetics. In order to expand her little business, she is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase fashionable clothing, handbags, shoes, and cosmetics to sell so that she will be able to attact more customers. This business expansion will allow her to increase her income so as to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Ne Lom le 26 Janvier 1949, Madame E. Dd Kafui est marie et a sa charge cinq (5) personnes. Retraite, son activit est axe sur la vente des produits vestimentaires et cosmtiques. Pour augmenter la taille de son activit, elle sollicite un financement pour sapprovisionner en nouveaut dhabits, sacs et chaussures et des produits cosmtiques afin dattirer plus de clientle. La ralisation de ce projet lui permettra daccrotre ses revenus pour un mieux tre de sa famille.

loan.use:
purchasing clothes, handbags, shoes, and cosmetics for resale in her boutique

Approvisionnement de sa boutique en habits, sacs, chaussures et produits cosmtiques.

loan.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Mrs. Khady N. was born in 1952, is married and is a member of the Village Banking group of Khodoba. She runs a small business selling kola nuts and jujube in order to provide for her family's needs. She has been a client of the program for four years and has always respected her obligations. The loan she is requesting now will be her 8th and will be for a six-month term with one payment at the end.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Khady N., marie, ne en 1952, membre du Banc villageois de Khodoba. Elle mne une activit de petit commerce de colas, de petits colas et de jujube afin de subvenir la satisfaction des besoins de sa famille. Elle est cliente du Programme depuis 4 ans et a toujours respect ses engagements. Ce prt quelle sollicite sera son 8me prt qui sera de 6 mois avec un seul paiement la fin.

loan.use: To buy merchandise

loan.name: Hadira

texts.en: Hadira was born in 1950 and she is married. She is from Motre, a suburb of Visoko. Her husband is a pensioner and his monthly pension is 370 KM. They have two children, 31 and 37 years old. This is her second loanof 1500 KM and she wants to invest it in agriculture. Hadira wants to expand her business in order to improve the living standards of her family.

loan.use: Invest in agriculture.

loan.name: Irene Adakou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Irne Adakou A. was born in Lom on February 7, 1965. She is single but is the breadwinner for 4 other persons. Her business is selling fried yams. She is requesting a loan which will allow her to stock a bigger quantity of yams and oil so that she can better satisfy the need of her customers and increase her income. Her dynamic personality and cleverness make her very likely to succeed in this business venture.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame A. Adakou Irne est ne Lom, le 07 Fvrier 1965. Clibataire, elle a en charge quatre (4) personnes. Son activit est base sur la vente de frite digname. Elle sollicite un financement qui va lui servir de sapprovisionner en grande quantit dignames et dhuile pour mieux satisfaire sa clientle et accrotre ses revenus. Le dynamise et habilet de cette dame constituent autant datouts pour le succs de ce projet.

loan.use:
Stocking yams and cooking oil

Stockage d'ignames et d'huile

loan.name: Ngen

texts.en: Mrs. Ngen T., 45, lives in Teok Nem in Kandal province. She was married, but is now divorced from her husband. She has two children who work in a factory each earning about $2 per day. Now, she would like to request a loan to buy two cows to (i) help her on a rice field and (ii) raise for breeding.

loan.use: To buy two cows

loan.name: Kossi Akakpo

texts.fr:
Born in Anfoin (Province of the Lakes) on December 31, 1961, Mr. Kossi Akakpo K. is married and is the father of eight children. A customs officer who is presently jobless, Mr. K. has a little shed that he would like to outfit as a general store. In order to do that, he is requesting a Kiva loan that he plans to use to purchase goods so as to open his little grocery shop for the people in his neighborhood. This will allow him to increase his income and improve living conditions for his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

N Anfoin (P/Lacs) le 31 dcembre 1961, Monsieur K. Akakpo Kossi est mari et pre de huit (8) enfants. Dclarant en douane sans emploi, il dispose dun petit magasin quil veut ramnager en boutique pour la vente des produits dalimentation gnrale. Pour cela il sollicite travers ce projet un prt qui lui servira de sapprovisionner en marchandises et ouvrir sa boutique dalimentation gnrale pour les habitants de son quartier. Ceci lui permettra daccrotre ses revenus et ainsi amliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loan.use:
Stocking merchandise for re-sale

Approvisionnement en marchandises

loan.name: Suriya's Group

texts.en:
My name is Suriya A. from a small town Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. I moved to this town 40 years ago from Pakistans second largest city Lahore. I am married and a mother of seven: three boys and four girls. Three of my daughters and two of my sons are married and live separately from us. My husband and one of my son sells pesticides and medicines used to kill white ants. They have set up their shop within our house. They now need to buy these medicines in bulk for their shop.

The other women who also need loans are:

Koser B., who runs a lumberyard, Shahida B., whose husband sells ladies' shoes,

Shahida H. needs this loan to help with her family's poultry farm,

Parween B. will invest this loan in her family's breakfast cafe,

Suriya B. wants to buy a dairy cow with her share of loan;and

Suriya B. is borrowing to help her family's fruit business.

loan.use: To buy more pesticides

loan.name: Kireka C2 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Christine A.. She is currently in the business of mushroom selling and is requesting a loan to add capital. Christine is 33 years old and is single. She has 3 children ranging from age 3.5 to 11 and her children go to school. Each week, Christine makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Christine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Christine is joined in her small group by Jaliya N., Sarah N., Jackline K., and Sylvia K.. Jaliya N. has a business in poultry keeping and wants to expand her business. Sarah N. is currently operating a canteen business and wants a loan to increase stock. Jackline K. operates a retail shop business and wants to purchase a fridge. Sylvia K. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth materials.

loan.use: To boost mushroom business

loan.name: Abdel Ramane

texts.fr:
Born in Bnin on December 16, 1979, Mr. Abdel Ramane A. had to forsake his studies after the death of his father and take up the sale of electrical goods such as light bulbs, electrical wire, switches etc., to earn his living. Very ambitious, he would like to expand his business venture, but he lacks the capital needed to do so. He is asking for a loan that he plans to use to purchase items that his clientele has asked for so as to increase his income from the business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

N au Bnin le 16 Dcembre 1979, Monsieur A. Abdel Ramane, a d abandonn ses tudes aprs le dcs de son pre pour se lancer dans le commerce de matriels lectriques savoir : ampoule, fil courant, interrupteur et autres afin de se prendre en charge. Trs ambitieux, il veut dvelopper son activit mais les moyens lui manquent. Il sollicite un financement qui lui servira dacqurir de nouveaux matriels sollicits par sa clientle et aussi renforcer sa capacit financire dans ce genre dactivit.

loan.use:
Purchase and re-sale of electrical goods

Achat et vente de matriels lectriques

loan.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Khady S. is married and has been a member of the Village Bank of Khodoba for seven years. She wants to build up her business selling fruit and vegetables, such as clementines and watermelons, in order to increase her investment. This would be her 15th loan. She is a serious client who has never had a problem repaying her loans. The planned duration of the loan is six months, and repayments will be made all at once at the end of term.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mme Khady S., marie, elle est membre du Banc villageois de Khodoba depuis 7 ans. Elle veut renforcer son commerce de fruits et lgumes comme les clmentines et les pastques afin daugmenter son investissement. Elle sollicite un 15me prt. C'est une clientle srieuse qui n'a jamais eu de problme pour rembourser ses prts. La dure prvue du prt est 6 mois et le remboursement se fera en une seule fois la fin.

loan.use: To buy merchandise to sell

loan.name: Alice's Group

texts.en: I am Alice Y. M.. I am in my late forties, married and a mother of five: two boys and three girls. My husband is a retired army junior officer who earns income by transporting goods on his donkey cart. My group members are Khalida S. and Nazira B., who are both borrowing to help with their familys sawdust businesses. Sawdust is used as fuel in small villages and towns here in Pakistan. All of us have known each other for a long time and often help each other in times of need.

loan.use: To buy an additional donkey cart for her son

loan.name: Parween's Group

texts.en:
I am Parween A. from the small city of Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. I have four children: three girls and one boy. All of my children attend school except for my youngest daughter who is not of school-going age yet. I send my children to school so that they can become good citizens. This is my third loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. My husband operates a wholesale business of sweets and candies. He hopes to improve his business by obtaining a loan to invest in his business. My group members who are also in need of loans are:

Basheera B., who wants to buy a cow; and

Khursheed B., who is borrowing to expand her fruit business.

loan.use: To improve my sweets and candies business

loan.name: Kireka C2 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane N.. She is currently in the business of running a canteen and selling clothes and is requesting a loan to add to both businesses. Jane is 45 years old and is a widow. She has 8 children ranging from age 11 to 28 and her children go to school. Each week, Jane makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her children's education. Jane has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jane is joined in her small group by Hanifha M., Fatuma N., Milly N., and Florence S.. Hanifha M. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to increase her inventory. Fatuma N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to boost business. Milly N. operates a canteen business and wants to purchase more snacks and edibles. Florence S. is currently in the business of running a bar and is requesting a loan to uplift business.

loan.use: To add stock to canteen

loan.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr:
Born in the district of Vo, Madame Kossiwa M. is married and the mother of four children and responsible for three other people. Her job is based on the commerce of foodstuffs and other diverse items such as soap, canned food, pasta etc. To finance this project, she is asking for a loan to be able to stock her merchandise better and to purchase food from wholesale distributors, making the purchase economically advantageous. This will allow her to avoid frequent ruptures in her stock and to better satisfy her customer demand with the goal of increasing her revenues and her profits.

Translated from French to English by Kvia Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Ne dans la prfecture de Vo, Madame M. Kossiwa est marie et mre de quatre (4) enfants et a en charge trois (3) autres personnes. Son activit est base sur le commerce de denres alimentaires et de divers (savons, bote de conserve, ptes alimentaire etc.) A travers ce projet, elle sollicite un financement pour pouvoir augmenter son stock en marchandises et se ravitailler chez les grossistes ce qui lavantage plus. Ceci lui permettra dviter les frquentes ruptures de stock et mieux satisfaire sa clientle en vue daccrotre ses revenus et ses bnfices.

loan.use: The stock and sale of merchandise.

loan.name: Aby

texts.fr:
Aby HANNE, born in 1952, is a widow. She has been a member of the Village Bank of Khodoba for five years. She is requesting this 11th loan to bolster her stock of fruit for sale (mandarines, oranges, clementines, watermelons, etc.). With the income generated from her business, she succeeds in supporting her family. She would like to repay this loan in one single payment at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mme Aby HANNE, est ne en 1952, veuve de son tat. Elle est membre du Banc villageois de Khodoba depuis 5 ans. Elle sollicite un 11me prt afin de renforcer son stock de marchandises en fruits (Mandarine, orange, clmentine, pastque, etc.). Avec les revenus gnrs par son activit, Aby russit prendre en charge sa famille. Elle propose de rembourser ce prt au bout de 6 mois en une seule chance.

loan.use: To buy merchandise to sell

loan.name: Kireka C2 C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Harriet N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Harriet is 27 years old and is married. She has 2 children aged 2.5 and 5 and one of them goes to school. Each week, Harriet makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her children's education. Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Ruth N., Harriet K., Rebecca N., and Rose N.. Ruth N. has a business running a grocery store and wants to purchase more groceries. Harriet K. is currently operating a canteen business and wants a loan to add to the business. Rebecca N. operates a business of charcoal sales and wants to expand to bulk selling. Rose N. is currently in the business of selling ripe bananas and is requesting a loan to add stock.

loan.use: To expand tailoring business

loan.name: Mbalwa A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Naluwaga M.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair oils and chemicals. Naluwaga is 37 years old and is married with a husband who is a builder. She has 5 children ranging from age 7 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Naluwaga makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for the children. Naluwaga has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Naluwaga is joined in her small group by Eunice M., Gladys B., Catherine N., and Florence N.. Eunice M. has a business selling snacks and wants to boost business. Gladys B. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to add more stock. Catherine N. operates a business of poultry farming and wants to buy more chicks and chicken feed. Florence N. is currently in the business of matooke selling and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loan.use: To add in salon business and widen customer base

loan.name: Amlia Akouvi

texts.fr:
At 35 years old, Madame Amelia Akouvi G. is divorced and a single mother of one child. A trained seamstress, she now sells traditional style skirts, purses and jewelry in her clothing store. Noticing that customer demand has been increasing, and because of her difficult financial situation, she is asking for a loan to purchase, according to the demand from customers, new traditional style skirts,purses, and jewelry so that she can finally fit out her clothing store. This will allow her to attract more customers and to increase her revenue.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Age de 35 ans, Madame G. Akouvi Amlia est divorce et a sa charge un enfant. Couturire de formation, elle associe la vente de pagnes, sacs de sortie et bijoux son activit de couture. Remarquant que la demande tant si grande par rapport ses moyens financiers, elle sollicite travers ce projet un prt pour acheter, selon la demande de sa clientle, des nouveauts de pagnes, sacs, et bijoux afin de les satisfaire et amnager son atelier de couture. Cela lui permettra dattirer plus de clientle et daugmenter son revenu

loan.use: Fitting out of a clothing store and the purchase and sales of traditional style skirts.

loan.name: Ida Kokoe Ayi

texts.fr:
At 45 years old, Madame Ida Kokoe Ayi K. is married and the mother of five children. Previously being an operator, she quickly left this job to start her own business selling telephone recharge cards. Being a very friendly person, she quickly attracted many customers and now she is often confronted with diminished stock. In order to improve her business, she is asking for a loan in order to ensure she will always have sufficient stock and be able to satisfy customer demand. With realization of this dream will give her higher revenue and consequently an improved standard of living for her family.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Age de 45 ans, Madame K. Ayi Koko Ida est marie et mre de cinq (5) enfants. Etant Opratrice de saisie, elle a vite laiss cet emploi et sest lance dans le commerce de vente de cartes de recharge. Trs accueillante, elle a su vite avoir plus de clientle et maintenant, elle est souvent confront de frquente rupture de stock. Pour mettre fin cette situation, elle sollicite un financement afin davoir en permanence de stock et satisfaire la demande de sa clientle. A travers ce rve, elle disposera dun revenu sur pour la satisfaction des besoins de sa famille.

loan.use: Purchase and sale of recharge cards (mostly telephone related)

loan.name: Mbalwa B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Janet S.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to construct a charcoal shade and increase stock. Janet is 46 years old and is married. Her husband is a mechanic. She has 7 children ranging from age 19 to 28 and her children go to school. Each week, Janet makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Janet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Janet is joined in her small group by Florence N., Melisa N., Sarah S., and Mbaga P.. Florence N. has a business in poultry farming and wants to add to her business. Melisa N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to purchase more raw food and furniture. Sarah S. operates a business of charcoal selling and wants to add capital and expand the business. Mbaga P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling.

loan.use: To expand charcoal business to bulk selling

loan.name: Meheza

texts.fr:
Born in Lom on May 10, 1982, Ms. Mhza K. is single and lives in the district of Forever. Her principal economic activity is the sale of various products in her Brasserie-Bar. Because she does not have the sufficient funds, she is asking for a loan in order to restock her Bar. These funds will help her to increase her revenue and to create other small businesses including the sale of beauty products.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Ne Lom le 10 Mai 1982, Mlle K. Mhza est clibataire et rside au quartier Forever. Son activit principale est la vente des produits de la Brasserie sous forme de Bar. Avec ses moyens trs insuffisants, elle dcide d 'avoir un prt pour ravitailler le Bar. Ce fond lui servira daccrotre son revenu et de crer dautres activits associes aux produits de beaut.

loan.use: To restock drinks in her bar.

loan.name: Kayi Adakou Dovi

texts.fr:
Born in 1960, Madame Kayi Adakou Dovi is married and responsible for supporting four people in her family. To make money, she sells various products ranging from soaps, plastic objects, traditional style skirts, and jewelry. With her meager finances, she was able to start this small business, but needs a loan to help augment her store and to better satisfy her customers. To do this, she would like to buy a large quantity of items in order to attract more customers. The funds from the loan will permit her to increase her revenue and finance other products on request from customers. This will also allow her to improve the standard of living of her family and above all, aid and improve the education of her children.

Translation from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Ne en 1960, Madame K. Dovi Adakou Kayi est marie et supporte quatre (4) personnes. Elle a pour activit la vente des produits divers (savons, objets plastiques, pagnes, bijoux) avec ses maigres moyens financiers. Pour mieux satisfaire ses clients, elle sollicite un financement qui lui servira dagrandir la taille de son commerce en achetant en grande quantit ses articles pour plus attirer la clientle. Ce fonds lui permettra daccrotre ses revenus et refinancer dautres produits selon la demande des clients. Ceci lui permettra damliorer les conditions de vie de la famille surtout lducation de ses enfants

loan.use: To purchase and sell plastic objects and other miscellaneous products.

loan.name: Zareena's Group

texts.en:
I am the leader of a group of 4 other women who also require loans to invest in their businesses:

Rani B. is borrowing to help with her familys sheep trading business,

Parween A. will invest her loan in her tailoring business,

Shamim A. is borrowing to help her son, who is a welder; and

Nazia N. plans to invest her loan in her husbands electronic store business. For myself, I am 48, married and a mother of ten: six boys and four girls. I am borrowing for my son who runs a musical band. He will use the loan to buy some new musical instruments.

loan.use: To buy musical instruments

loan.name: Mbalwa C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Getrude I.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Getrude is 33 years old and is married. Her husband is an artist. She has 2 children aged 15 and 17 and her children go to school. Each week, Getrude makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her children's education. Getrude has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 800000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Getrude is joined in her small group by Grace N., Maria N., Christine N., and Justine K.. Grace N. has a business in brick laying and wants to expand the business. Maria N. is currently operating a canteen business and wants a loan to add capital stock. Christine N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to purchase more salon equipment. Justine K. is currently in the business of poultry keeping and is requesting a loan to construct another poultry house and purchase more chicks.

loan.use: To boost tailoring business

loan.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
I am Azra B. and I live with my family in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. I am 35, married and a mother of seven: five girls and two daughters. All of my children could not attend school initially due to our family's poor economic conditions but now I have enrolled three of them in school. My husband runs a lumberyard and needs a loan to buy wood in bulk. My group members are:

Nasreen B. who needs this loan to expand her fruit-selling business,

Sharifan and Sughran B. who will buy a donkey cart each with their shares of the loan; and

Nazira B. who is borrowing money to help run her restaurant.

All these women are hardworking entrepreneurs and can be trusted to invest their loans in their respective businesses.

loan.use: To buy wood for a lumberyard

loan.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Monsieur Kodjo A. was born in 1982 in Lom, where he continues to live. A bachelor, he opened a cafeteria-cafe, financed by his meager savings. So as to improve this endeavor, he is asking for a loan which will aid him in purchasing sufficient provisions for his cafeteria-cafe so as to run smoothly, such as milk, sugar, coffee, and eggs among others. With these provisions, he hopes to expand his current cafeteria-cafe into a restaurant, because his customer demand is very high. Completing this project will make it so that he does not have to go to the market every day, which leaves him more time to run his store and will result in higher revenue which he sorely needs to improve his daily standard of living.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Monsieur A. Kodjo est n en 1982 et rside Lom. Clibataire, il dtient une caftria finance par ses maigres moyens. A partir de ce projet, il sollicite un prt afin de sapprovisionner en quantit suffisante de lait, sucre, caf, ufs et autres, et faire dautres provisions pour un restaurant sur la demande de sa clientle. La ralisation de ce projet lui permettre de ne plus aller tous les jours au march et ainsi augmenter ses revenus en vue damliorer ses conditions de vie

loan.use: To buy provisions for his cafeteria-cafe.

loan.name: Comite Los Arrabales Group

texts.en:
This comit of women called Barrio Los Arrabales has arisen with the help of another committee of women entrepreneurs. Today this group has nineteen members and their businesses range from convenience stores to hair salons, clothing and food sales, and mending and making clothing.

These women do what they can to keep the money coming in. They all support each other by working in this committee and together they ask for loans and pay their loans back. This system works because they are all friends who are invested in each others businesses and who care about each others personal lives.

The women are asking for a loan today to keep their businesses running. The money will be divided amongst the women according to how much each needs and will be used to buy ingredients for preparing food, for clothing, and household goods.

loan.use: To buy flour, canned goods, milk, drinks, pieces of clothing, buttons, zippers, thread, fabric, shoes, hair products, baked goods, and baking ingredients.

loan.name: Manzar

texts.en:
G. Manzar sells fruit and vegetables in a shop that is close to her house. She lives with her son and her husband. She has been in this business for 7 years and this is the first time that she has needed a loan. Her son has an old car that they use when they go to wholesale points of the city. Her husband retired and he just joined her in trying to improve their business together.

They need funds to repair the fruit shop from the inside and outside so it looks nice. They also would like to add a couple of shelves. People that live near her buy fruits and vegetables only from her to support her business.

loan.use: To repair and improve her fruit and vegetable shop

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Ahliba

texts.fr:
Madame Ahliba B. was born in 1966. She is married and the mother of three children. She is a saleswoman of food products, an activity that has been very profitable but still needs a larger investment. To better satisfy her customers, Madame B. is asking for a loan that will allow her to reinforce her purchasing power and to buy larger stocks of corn and rice. This will allow her to see her revenue increase and better support the needs of her family.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Madame B. Ahliba est ne en 1966, marie et mre de trois (3) enfants. Elle est revendeuse des produits alimentaires, une activit trs rentable mais qui ncessite plus de fonds. Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientele, Madame B. Ahliba sollicite un financement qui va lui permettre de renforcer son pouvoir dachat et constituer un stock de mais.et de riz. Ceci lui permettra daccrotre ses revenus et de mieux soccuper des besoins de sa famille

loan.use: To stock corn and rice.

loan.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa B. is married with her own house and two children, ages 10 and 15. They are in school while she works in a convenience store of her own. She sells various goods and has a good amount of meat that she sells as well. This makes her business competitive.

She is asking for a loan today to help her pay all the necessary bills including electricity and water, however, she wishes to invest most of the money in buying necessary goods like flour, oil, rice, and yerba mate.

loan.use: To buy merchandise like sugar, flour, rice, Yerba Mate, and pasta.

loan.name: Zulma

texts.en:
Zulma R. is a single mother of two children. She lives in the San Roque neighborhood of Encarnacion with her younger daughter. The other daughter is married and living with her husband. She only hopes that her younger daughter will continue with schooling and go on to have a profession in life.

For more than 12 years, Zulma has owned a store in a good number of clientele since she has been in business for so many years running, and she wants help now to expand her store. With the loan she will buy more remedies in bulk and therefore have the ability to charge less, making her business more competitive.

loan.use: To buy natural remedies at a good price

loan.name: Ayaovi

texts.fr:
Born in Lom on July 9, 1982, Mr. Ayaovi Z. is a young electrician for a building unit. He still lives and works in Lom, in the district of N'Kafu. From a rather poor family, he was only recently able to finish his apprenticeship diploma. Very ambitious, he is asking for a loan which will allow him to purchase materials he needs for work and to open a workshop with the goal to exercise his trade to its full potential. This will make it possible for him to expand his business and take charge of his career and his future.

Translated by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

N Lom le 09 Juillet 1981, Monsieur Z. Ayaovi est un jeune lectricien en btiment et rside Lom au quartier NKafu. Issu dune famille trs pauvre, il a tout rcemment eu son diplme de fin dapprentissage. Trs ambitieux, il sollicite un financement qui lui servira dacqurir les matriels et outils de travail et ouvrir un atelier afin dexercer pleinement son mtier. Ceci lui permettra de mieux spanouir et se prendre en charge

loan.use: To purchase materials he needs for work.

loan.name: Kokouvi

texts.fr:
Mr. Kokouvi K. was born in Lom on December 31, 1979. He is married and the father of two children, with four other children in his care. A driver by profession, he works for a third party as a taxi driver and makes daily returns. Through this project, he is asking for a loan of $1,000 with which to buy his own vehicle so that he can fully enjoy the fruits of his labor. This will enable him to better meet the needs of his family and grant him financial independence.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur K. Kokouvi est n Lom le 31 dcembre 1979. Mari, il est pre de 2 enfants, il a en charge quatre 04) autres enfants. Chauffeur de profession, il travail pour un tiers comme conducteur de taxi et fait les recettes journalires. A travers se projet, il sollicite un financement de $1000 pour acqurir un vhicule de transport propre lui-mme afin de jouir pleinement des fruits de son travail. Cela lui permettra de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille et lui donnera une autonomie financire.

loan.use: To buy a taxi

loan.name: Kua Aty De Ita Group

texts.en:
The beginning of the group Kua Aty was in November 2006. One of the members, Hermogena T., began this group of women entrepreneurs, most of whom were neighbors and all whom were friends. All of the women were interested because they all wanted to support each other in their different businesses including: grocery, crafts, drinks, fruits, and lingerie and basket sales.

Kua Aty has a total of 16 women entrepreneurs who meet regularly to collect the loan payments and discuss their businesses. Each woman takes home the appropriate amount of money she needs for her business. Together they are aksing for a loan to help increase their businesses profits. With the money they will buy goods like food, baking goods, and clothing items.

loan.use: buy goods like food, baking goods, and clothing items.

loan.name: Alfred

texts.fr:
A paternal orphan, Mr. Alfred A. was born in Lom on September 14, 1963, is married and has four children. After high school he trained as a farmer, specializing in the rearing of pigs and small ruminants. Gifted in pig farming, he is requesting financing to increase the size of the shelter he uses for raising pigs and also start breeding other kinds of animal that are particularly requested by his customers. Achieving this dream will allow him to better satisfy his customers and increase his income in order to better meet the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Orphelin de pre, Monsieur A. Alfred est n Lom le 14 septembre 1963, mari et pre de quatre (4) enfants. Aprs ses tudes secondaires, il suit une formation en agriculture avec spcialisation en levage de porcins et de petits ruminants. Dou dans llevage du porc, il sollicite un financement afin dlargir sa superficie dexploitation en loge de porcs et galement procder laccouplement dautres races surtout demandes par sa clientles. La ralisation de ce rve lui permettra de mieux satisfaire sa clientle et augmenter ses revenus en vue de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille

loan.use: Pig Farming

loan.name: Javid

texts.en:
Javid M. has been reselling cars for 10 years. He is an expert mechanic. In his business, he purchases one car at a time, performs a tune up, and any major repairs that are necessary. Then he details and resells the car for profit.

Mr. M. is an internally displaced person (IDP) from Aghdam and his business is in Baku. He is married and has two children. The car pictured is a good vehicle that will bring him a substantial profit, but he needs this loan to buy used spare parts. Javid is a community man who provides reliable vehicles to other IDPs in his community.

loan.use: To buy spare parts for his auto repair business.

loan.name: Kua Katupyry Of Ita Group

texts.en:
This group of women is named Kua Katupyry of Ita, and it was begun in October 2006 by a woman who wanted to help her neighbors and friends increase the profits from their businesses. She gathered them together and now they are working with Fundacin Paraguaya to increase their business capacities. They all work independently and sell things like groceries, clothing, cosmetics, and home goods.

At the moment the group is made up of 15 women entrepreneurs and was formed in the city of Capiata. They meet regularly to discuss business methods, learn about good business practices with a representative from Fundacin Paraguaya, and support each others business and their families. Today, they are asking for a loan to increase their merchandise.

loan.use: buying business goods like clothing, shirts, pants, perfumes, facial creams, food, meat, refreshments, and baking goods

loan.name: Neli
